image.altText: Defence Minister Richard Marles

props.synopsis: Australia's projected defence spending will increase by another $50 billion over the next decade, the defence minister has revealed in releasing Labor's long-awaited National Defence Strategy.

title.children: Richard Marles unveils $50 billion defence spending increase over next decade

image.altText: A young man poses for a photo on a cliff face, with mountains behind him.

props.synopsis: University student Benjamin Cohen was falsely accused of being the stabber behind the Bondi Junction Westfield attack on Saturday, following misinformation that was spread online.

title.children: Man wrongly identified as Bondi Junction stabber pursues defamation case against Network Seven

image.altText: A composite image of a man holding knife and man with surfboard

props.synopsis: A month ago, Joel Cauchi's parents were relieved to see a text message showing him enjoying life at the beach. Next time they saw him it was on national television as he attacked people in a Sydney shopping centre.

title.children: At 17, Joel Cauchi was diagnosed with schizophrenia. But his path to murdering six people started five years ago

image.altText: A man sitting looking at flowers in a tribute at Bondi Junction shopping centre.

props.synopsis: The shopping mall at the centre of Saturday's fatal stabbings in Sydney will reopen tomorrow for a community reflection day, before resuming normal trading hours on Friday.

title.children: Bondi Junction mall to reopen tomorrow for community reflection after fatal stabbing attack

image.altText: An image of Brittany Higgins next to an image of Bruce Lehrmann.

props.synopsis: Justice Michael Lee leaned in to the Shakespearean tragedy of Bruce Lehrmann's case and with the narrative muscularity of a literary thriller showed simplicity and complexity need not be enemies. As his judgment took form it became clear he had an altogether more useful verdict in mind.

title.children: The public battle between 'Team Higgins' and 'Team Lehrmann' revealed the most frightening trap of tribalism

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann outside the ACT Supreme Court with a serious expression, wearing glasses and a tie. He has a beard.

props.synopsis: What happened between Bruce Lehrmann and Brittany Higgins in a ministerial suite at Parliament House in March 2019 has triggered at least a dozen avenues of legal action so far — and the costs of all this litigation are set to be many millions.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's costs in failed defamation case set to be astronomically high

image.altText: A woman smiles and poses for a photo that has been overlayed with a sepia filter, adjusting the colour to give it a yellow tone

props.synopsis: Rachael Dixon, a 53-year-old Melbourne woman, died after ingesting a drink at a regional Victorian wellness centre that was made with mushrooms. Here's what we know.

title.children: Woman who died at wellness retreat consumed drink made with mushrooms

image.altText: Gavin Webb holds a bass while sitting on stage.

props.synopsis: One of the founding members of Australian rock band The Masters Apprentices, Gavin Webb, has died aged 77 after a six-year battle with cancer.

title.children: Founding member of The Masters Apprentices Gavin Webb dies

image.altText: woman leaning against a gate

props.synopsis: Jyles and Rainey Lebler say their mother wouldn't willingly leave them behind as they beg for information on the woman who was last seen checking out of a Gold Coast clinic in 1995.

title.children: Sons fight back tears in desperate plea for information on mum who disappeared from Gold Coast

image.altText: A green comet streaking through a star studded sky

props.synopsis: Australians will be able to see comet 12P/Pons-Brooks aka the 'Devil Comet' this week even without a telescope or binoculars. Here's how to spot it and snap a photo.

title.children: Want to see the 'Devil Comet' at its brightest? If you miss it, you’ll have to wait another 71 years

image.altText: Anthony Albanese holds up a dollar coin while standing in the House of Representatives

props.synopsis: The good news is there's likely to be some change to Australia's HELP scheme, and we're likely to hear about it soon, in the lead-up to the May budget. The bad news for borrowers is it won't be debt relief of the kind Biden is offering.

title.children: Albanese's budget will likely include changes to student debt. Here's what that could look like

image.altText: A plane on a runway with high water around it

props.synopsis: Dubai's major international airport diverts scores of incoming flights as heavy rains flood the United Arab Emirates after leaving 18 dead in Oman.

title.children: Heavy rains lash Middle East, disrupting flights in Dubai after killing 18 in Oman

image.altText: A man looks at stock prices through the window of the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is trading flat on Wednesday as investors ponder global interest rates after comments by the US Federal Reserve suggesting inflation hasn't been hosed down. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Supermarket inquiry slammed as 'populism' as former ACCC chair ponders if retailers are actually gouging

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Recipients' shares surge on government's critical minerals funding announcement
Rio Tinto's first quarter iron ore shipments fall by 5%
Bondi Junction Westfield will resume normal trading hours on Friday

image.altText: A man looks at a computer screen. He is wearing glasses.

props.synopsis: Andrew Ryder was recovering from a $10,000 fraud attack when his Optus account was hacked a second time.

title.children: Optus customer who lost $10,000 from bank will leave telco after second fraud attack

image.altText: Horse in a stable.

props.synopsis: The Wagga Wagga City Council says the horses appear to have been slaughtered over a long period of time, with some killed "relatively recently".

title.children: More than 500 horse carcasses found at NSW property

image.altText: A happy smiling woman wearing glasses and a brightly coloured scarf over a dark blouse.

props.synopsis: Liberal senator Linda Reynolds has responded to the Federal Court's judgement in the defamation case brought by Bruce Lehrmann against Network 10 and Lisa Wilkinson, saying she is beyond pleased the court "has set the record straight" about her treatment of Brittany Higgins.

title.children: Linda Reynolds says Lehrmann defamation judgement 'set record straight' on claims of cover-up

image.altText: nsw police officers conduct a line search after multiple stabbings in doonside

props.synopsis: Three teenagers are due before a children's court today after attending Blacktown Police Station last night.

title.children: Four teenagers charged with murder after fatal stabbing at Doonside in Sydney's west on Friday

image.altText: View of the High Court of Australia sign in Canberra.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for an Iranian man demanding to be released from detention have told the High Court their client would be prepared to be sent to anywhere other than Iran, even war-ravaged Gaza.

title.children: Lawyers tell High Court Iranian man facing deportation would rather be sent to Gaza than back to Iran

image.altText: A young woman comforts an older man holding a stress ball

props.synopsis: Older Australians fear their voices are being drowned out in favour of powerful industry groups who have greater influence over government.

title.children: You might have missed them, but here are some of the big changes coming in aged care

image.altText: Three faces from the community

props.synopsis: For many in Sydney's Assyrian community, the images of violence at the Christ The Good Shepherd Church on Monday evening brought flashbacks of war.

title.children: 'It's like an exposed nerve': Assyrians express raw emotions following Sydney stabbing and riot

image.altText: Harpinder Singh looks at the camera at night in Alice Springs.

props.synopsis: After nearly three weeks, kids under the age of 18 are now allowed in the Alice Springs CBD at night. Locals are calling for long-term action to prevent crime from spiralling out of control.

title.children: Alice Springs has experienced its first night post-curfew. Here's how locals feel

image.altText: A woman sits on a couch with two dogs and a magpie.

props.synopsis: After more than six weeks apart, the Insta-famous magpie and its best dog friends are back together at home on the Gold Coast — singing and sunning themselves like old times.

title.children: Molly the magpie singing with joy as video of long-awaited reunion with canine best friend released

image.altText: An oil sketch of donald trump wearing a blue suit looking upset

props.synopsis: Seven jury members are selected on the second day of Donald Trump's trial at the Manhattan Criminal Court where he is charged with falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal.

title.children: Trump told off for 'muttering' as first jurors selected in hush money trial

image.altText: A size comparison of three black holes next to each other.

props.synopsis: Astronomers have discovered the second-largest black hole known to be in the Milky Way, and it's located just 2,000 light-years from Earth.

title.children: Astronomers detect Milky Way black hole with mass 33 times that of the Sun

image.altText: A cane toad's head.

props.synopsis: The cane toad is spreading in northern Australia, but researchers have found a way to protect apex predators from the toxic pest and it's all a matter of taste.

title.children: Researchers unleash 'teacher toads' in bid to stop goannas eating deadly pest

image.altText: A Port Adelaide AFL footballer holds the ball in both hands as he runs and looks downfield.

props.synopsis: After apologising for a homophobic slur against an opponent, Port Adelaide's Jeremy Finlayson vents his frustration at the resulting three-match ban on a podcast that has since been edited.

title.children: Port Adelaide's Finlayson vents frustration on wife's podcast over ban for homophobic slur

image.altText: woman lays on her couch looking at her laptop

props.synopsis: Helping women find the language to describe their persistent pelvic pain symptoms can improve their chances of receiving the right care.

title.children: Talking to doctors about pelvic pain requires a language many of us don't have

image.altText: People lay flowers in a mall.

props.synopsis: Waverley Council says the site of the killing spree is becoming hallowed ground as it works to help the community express its grief over the shocking attacks.

title.children: Candlelight vigil, permanent memorial planned to honour victims of Bondi stabbing attacks

image.altText: A sign that says "Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority" on a wall outside a government building.

props.synopsis: Barnaby Joyce's 2016 decision to move Australia's pesticides regulator to regional NSW "caused massive chaos and disruption", according to Agriculture Minister Murray Watt, who has decided to ignore calls to move it back to Canberra.

title.children: Agency probed over Christmas party urination claims will not move back to Canberra

image.altText: A "sorry we're closed" sign in the window of a shopfront.

props.synopsis: Australia's economic cracks are widening, with a record number of businesses now under external administration and many heading for collapse under the weight of weak demand, rising costs and large tax debts.

title.children: The cracks in Australia's economy are starting to appear as business insolvencies hit record highs

props.synopsis: The AFP Victim Identification Team are often parents themselves, tasked with solving some of the most grim and shocking crimes humans commit. For them, disconnecting from work is a necessity.

title.children: Sergeant Kate Laidler trained to be a PE teacher. She never imagined spending her work days tracking down predators
